title: 105_hr1655
content: The Act titled "Limited Purpose Bank Amendments of 1997" restricts bank activities. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include regulations on bank subsidiaries that accept demand deposits and engage in commercial lending activities. Loans made in the ordinary course of a credit card operation are not considered commercial loans. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to regulate bank subsidiaries accepting demand deposits and engaging in commercial lending activities, including restrictions on overdrafts for affiliates. Additionally, regulations on the acquisition of credit card assets are updated. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to regulate bank subsidiaries engaging in activities permitted for certain institutions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to regulate bank subsidiaries engaging in activities permitted for certain institutions. The act includes a cross-marketing restriction and a restriction on daylight overdrafts. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include permissible overdrafts for affiliates monitored by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, fully secured by bonds or obligations. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to allow affiliates monitored by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to have permissible overdrafts fully secured by bonds or obligations guaranteed by the United States. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to allow affiliates monitored by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to have permissible overdrafts fully secured by bonds or obligations guaranteed by the United States, in accordance with the provisions of the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. SEC. 5. RESTRICTION ON ACQUISITIONS OF OTHER INSURED DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS. Amends the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 to restrict acquisitions of undercapitalized insured institutions. SEC. 6. DIVESTITURE REQUIREMENT. Amendment to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 requires companies to divest control of banks if they lose exemption status within 180 days of notification from the Board. The amendment to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 mandates companies to divest control of banks if they fail to qualify for exemption or do not correct the condition within a year as per the Board's approval. Additionally, companies must implement procedures to prevent a recurrence of the issue. The company described in paragraph (1) will lose the exemption if they no longer qualify.
